question: Question_01_(f)
statement:
What is the average value of $\left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|$ over
the interval $0\leq\theta\leq\pi/2$ ?
sols:
(The following solution does not take advantage of the symmetry about
$\theta=\pi/4$. Solution 2 does.)\\

The average value of $\left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|$ over the
interval $0\leq\theta\leq\pi/2$ is\\\begin{align*}
f_{ave}=\frac{1}{\pi/2} \int_0^{\pi/2} \left|\sin\theta-\cos\theta\right|d\theta.
\end{align*}\\ In order to simplify the absolute value, we split the
domain of integration into regions where $\sin\theta-\cos\theta$ is
positive and negative. Then\\ \begin{align*}
f_{ave}&=\frac{2}{\pi} \left(\int_0^{\pi/4} (\cos\theta - \sin\theta) d\theta +\int_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2}(\sin\theta - \cos\theta) d\theta\right)\\
&=\frac{2}{\pi} \left(\left[\sin\theta + \cos\theta\right]_0^{\pi/4}  +\left[ -\cos\theta - \sin\theta\right]_{\pi/4}^{\pi/2} \right)\\
&=\frac{2}{\pi} \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt2} +\frac{1}{\sqrt2}-0-1 -0-1 +\frac{1}{\sqrt2} +\frac{1}{\sqrt2} \right)\\
&=\frac{2}{\pi} \left( \frac{4}{\sqrt2} -2 \right)\\
&=\frac{4}{\pi} \left( \sqrt2 -1 \right)
\end{align*}
hints:
Where is $\sin\theta - \cos\theta$ equal to zero? Where is it positive?
Where is it negative?
